channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Songs of Love writes personalized music for kids — but can AI carry the tune?
item.description: For nearly 30 years, the nonprofit Songs of Love Foundation has created custom songs for kids with terminal illnesses. Now it has harnessed AI to expand its services to older adults with memory loss.

item.title: The mayor of a General Motors factory town on the impact of new tariffs
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep asks Mayor Andy Schor of Lansing, Mich., about the potential impact of tariffs on the city that is home to two General Motors plants.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: The White House sets a swath of new tariff rates for dozens of countries, President Trump's Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff visits an aid site in Gaza, Jewish leaders from the U.S. sign a letter urging Israel to allow more aid into Gaza.

item.title: 'Mean Girl' Reneé Rapp isn't getting much nicer on 'Bite Me'
item.description: Reneé Rapp conquered Broadway in "Mean Girls" and the small screen on HBO Max's "The Sex Lives of College Girls." Now she's gunning for the pop charts. Her new album is called "Bite Me." {STATIONS NOTE: The word "fucking" is bleeped from the conversation at the 1:50 mark}

item.title: President Trump's Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff to visit an aid site in Gaza
item.description: President Trump's Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff visits an aid distribution site in Gaza, amid rising anger over a deepening hunger crisis in the territory.

item.title: The art of the praise
item.description: World leaders have lavished praise on President Trump in order to smooth diplomatic relations, and get better deals too.

item.title: Trump's 'Golden Share' in U.S. Steel
item.description: The iconic American company, U.S. Steel was sold to Nippon Steel in Japan earlier this summer. The sale was years in the making and, on the campaign trail last year, President Trump opposed it. But now, he's approved the sale. And the deal also gives the president himself an outsized say in the future of U.S. Steel. Erika Beras from Planet Money explains what the president calls: a golden share.

item.title: Use of AI in airlines ticket pricing raise concerns
item.description: Delta Air Lines has said it will use more AI in ticket pricing, which means you could be paying more or less for your next plane ride. Some lawmakers are concerned about fairness.

item.title: Jewish leaders from the U.S. sign a letter urging Israel to allow more aid into Gaza
item.description: More than a thousand rabbis and other Jewish leaders from the U.S. and elsewhere have signed a public letter urging Israel to allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza.

item.title: Rabbi Charles Feinberg on why he spoke out about starvation in Gaza
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks with Rabbi Charles Feinberg about why he joined over a thousand rabbis and Jewish leaders in publicly accusing Israel of using starvation as a weapon of war in Gaza.
